newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico peso closes mixed on pre-weekend swaps.
newsitem.headline: Mexico peso closes mixed on pre-weekend swaps.

text.p: Benchmark 48-hour peso contracts closed slightly weaker on Thursday after closing firmer for five straight sessions, due to swaps ahead of the weekend, traders said.
Nonetheless, traders said the peso shrugged off adverse circumstances.
"The peso still closed stronger than 7.80 per dollar, despite swaps and lack of dollar inflow," a trader said.
The benchmark 48-hour peso closed 0.7 of a centavo weaker at 7.7940/7.7960 per dollar, while its 24-hour stablemate was unchnaged at 7.7810/7.7830 per dollar.
Same-day peso contracts closed earlier 1.3 centavos firmer at 7.7740/7.7770 per dollar.
Dealers said 48-hour contracts were in heavy demand as they do not have to be settled until Tuesday because U.S. markets will be closed on Monday, February 17, for President's Day.
The advantage, they said, was that dollars could be sold in the same-day market and bought back at 48 hours, with pesos that may be invested in the money market for five days.
Traders differed as to whether or not the peso had scope to gain ground against the dollar.

"We feel there are more and more domestic players short on dollars who will not be able to hold out for long without squaring positions," a trader said. "It will be enough for one player to step in to buy dollars for the rest to follow suit."
Other traders felt the peso could head for resistance at 7.77 per dollar before receding to 7.80.
"The peso did not firm up today because they took profits on the bourse, but when the rally gets under way again then the peso could gain ground," another trader said.
Dealers said they would keep a close eye on reaction in the U.S. bond markets to Producer Price Index data due to be announced in early trade on Friday.
